results.content:
Html and css was great! The rest of the course came at the viewer like a fire hose. Not enough introduction to the elements of javascript, json, and jquery to fully  grasp the concepts in the first run without having to do some major side learning. Successful presentation but from a student perspective, I felt the lectures simply jumped into the application of frameworks and scripts by naming them only; operational definitions were necessary at a minimum.

Thank you all the same for the introduction.  The lessons have struck up an interest to further explore these methods.

Not enough introduction to the elements of javascript, json, and jquery to fully grasp the concepts in the first run without having to do some major side learning. Successful presentation but from a student perspective, I felt the lectures simply jumped into the application of frameworks and scripts by naming them only; operational definitions were necessary at a minimum.

Thank you all the same for the introduction. The lessons have struck up an interest to further explore these methods.

results.content:
The first sections were pretty good except for the bad parts. The bad includes the instructor reading word for word from his slides. He also was not properly prepared for some of his lectures so was "winging it" on the fly.

The UGLY was adding all the "features" you have to test for. This requires extra coding OR just abandoning a person viewing a web site all together.

He even contradicts him by declaring that it is "all about function" for a website then adds "cool features" that duplicates existing functions.

The purpose of websites that PAY to be developed is to convey information about the person, company and the services offered and generate business therefore income. Far too many add "entertainment" that does not of the above. Just because something is "cool" is not a reason to code it into a website.

In addition, most of the second half of the class required javascript which is "beyond the scope of this class".

Sometimes (most actually) it would have been to show the finished project, web page, or website THEN show how to get it done.

He did not talk a bit about planning the basic pages. He wasted time by not building just a page with everything that would be on every page. Then he should have "saved as" each page before coding. Every web page should have a "base" page to make it easy to add new "mother" or "daughter" pages (a subject completely omitted).

results.content: Overall, a good beginner course with some pleasant surprises along the way; I didn't expect to learn a lot of CSS, but it was integrated seamlessly and made even early-on coding much more interesting, and I certainly didn't expect to learn about client-side and server-side web storage. They even covered a little javascript too. The only reason I didn't give this a five star was because in Section 6, at least for me, it seemed like too many new concepts were being introduced at once when each could have used a more in-depth explanation, and at times the aforementioned javascript could get a little difficult for the same reason, though to a lesser degree. Section 6 aside, I would definitely recommend for people interested in getting into coding,
results.content_html: Overall, a good beginner course with some pleasant surprises along the way; I didn't expect to learn a lot of CSS, but it was integrated seamlessly and made even early-on coding much more interesting, and I certainly didn't expect to learn about client-side and server-side web storage. They even covered a little javascript too. The only reason I didn't give this a five star was because in Section 6, at least for me, it seemed like too many new concepts were being introduced at once when each could have used a more in-depth explanation, and at times the aforementioned javascript could get a little difficult for the same reason, though to a lesser degree. Section 6 aside, I would definitely recommend for people interested in getting into coding,

results.content:
O curso é bom, mas poderia ser melhor.
Pode-se ver que o instrutor tem conhecimento do assunto, mas é repetitivo em certas partes e pouco específico em outras.
O curso tem uma apresentação mediana e um enquadramento ruim de câmera. 
Ele cumpre o que promete, mas se vc não tiver paciência ou algum conhecimento anterior talvez desanime cedo. Eu não desanimei pq tinha muito interesse na geoloalização, cache e funções de arraste.
É um bom curso pra começar ou agregar outros conhecimentos (o útimo foi o meu caso).

results.content: This was a pretty good refresher/intro into HTML5.  I would not say it was comprehensive and/or polished presentation.  Lots of video editing could have been done to polish it.  I was excited to get to section 6 where we were going to create a web app with what we've learned.  Unfortunately the instructor moved way too fast, pretty much cheated by taking Bootstrap and then just modifying for the Daily Planner's needs.  It was still neat to see but didn't really bring everything from the previous sections together.  I left that section excited and confused.
results.content_html: This was a pretty good refresher/intro into HTML5. I would not say it was comprehensive and/or polished presentation. Lots of video editing could have been done to polish it. I was excited to get to section 6 where we were going to create a web app with what we've learned. Unfortunately the instructor moved way too fast, pretty much cheated by taking Bootstrap and then just modifying for the Daily Planner's needs. It was still neat to see but didn't really bring everything from the previous sections together. I left that section excited and confused.

results.content: This course is teaching me how to copy-paste the code from websites. There is a lecture named materialize in which mentor teaches us to visit a website select  feature that you want in you website like the navigation bar, Form etc. Copy the code and paste it in your HTML file and then voila you have built your website. And the portion we copy-paste is the most important portion of CSS which can make your website look really good. But the copy-paste code doesn't reveal the CSS part. The website doesn't provide the CSS code they only provide HTML code which has a link to CSS file. This is a waste of money and time.

results.content:
I am an experienced front end developer needing to get to grips with the fundamentals of HTML5 for a new Job.

I have previously used HTML5 syntax for page layout but not really used any of its functions. This course provided a good overview of the main HTML5 functions and how to implement them.

The tutor style is relaxed, and although he makes the occasional mistake whilst programming he explains things clearly, the mistakes actually are quite endearing and are typical of the mistakes made when developing so this is not an issue and actually highlights what can go wrong when coding.

There is a bit of Javascript in the tutorial, which is essential for HTML5, so some Javascript or other scripting language experience is useful, though not essential, as the tutor explains what he is doing as best as possible within the limited scope of the tutorials.

results.content:
The teacher references resources that are not provided. We are instructed to download files that do not exist. If they do exist, it is not at all easy to find. While some can be downloaded, they are mislabeled. When I am on Chapter 14, I have to use chapter 11 material - and so forth. Some resources just don't exist.
My advice to the teacher is to organize the materials so that they can be identified easily. For example: Section1, Section 2... Subdivide the sections into chapters, or if that is not practical, at least make it clear eg Lecture 3-6. Even if that is not practical, it coul dstill be done in a way that makes it possible to find the materials.
Also - put the resources at the BEGINNING of the section, rather than the end.
Advice to the learners: the lectures are ok, but very frustrating due to the above problems. He is knowledgeable, but also seems to fly by the seat of his pants. That is not all bad bc we can see how the process develops over time.

results.content:
I have completed the entire course.

It is important to know that sections 1 to 5 (6 hours of video) is THE MAIN COURSE taught by Leslie Zavarella. Sections 6 to 12 is an OLD ARCHIVE course taught by Brad Traversy which largely overlaps in same content but some of the non-overlapping content is outdated and redundant, although, there are some elements that are useful that isn't covered in the new course such as web storage and geolocation. Nevertheless, I completed both.

Quite frankly, the new course taught by Leslie is all you need and IMHO, a vastly superior course in the way its taught and delivered to engage you. That's not to say the old course (Brad's) is bad, far from it. Brad himself has a huge respected following on youtube and is revered but I feel he is very old school in the way he teaches and compared to Leslie's dynamic and engaging delivery. I find doing Brad's course to be very laborious but that's probably because I lack patience. But I consider Brad's course as bonus content, a reference for some elements not covered by Leslie.

So with that out of the way, I will purely focus my thoughts on Leslie's course (ie sections 1 to 5)

This course only costs twenty quid WITHOUT discount. So I expected just a basic introduction to HTML...from scratch as advertised.

I got so much more than that! In fact, after finishing Leslie's course, I had the confidence to build and publish my own desired website (and of course my first) complete with user form entry with data stored on the back end server. I never imagined I would reach this point with this course and in such a short space of time.

This is because the course delivers much more than what is advertised. Not only do we learn HTML and CSS but also, flexbox, CSS grid, frameworks (we use Materialize here), javascript, Git version control, and deploying live with backend user data storage. All of which provided me with a fantastic huge stepping stone into the wider world of web development but enough for me to create my own substantial website, right now with confidence. All I need to learn next is a couple of back end applications, like node.js and MySql or equivalent pairing to complete my personal website project.

But what astounds me is how quickly I got to this point. It literally only took me one week. I did one section per day (approx one hour).

This is all thanks to Leslie's energetic delivery and course structure. No preamble on PowerPoint theory, just a brief demo of what we aiming for and then we get down and dirty towards achieving the aim. It's exhilarating and hugely satisfying.

An important factor I place highly in my decision to buying an online course is support. I am glad to say that this course has a teaching assistant that is answering student questions almost every day and has been helping most students, although sometimes, I find he/she sometimes misunderstands the question. The course instructors do not answer as I think they were probably contracted for delivering the courses. But what matters is that there is a Q&A teaching assistant. Big chunky tick in the box!. Well done.

Every section has a quiz comprising 5 questions. That is welcome but if you get any wrong, you don't get any explanations for why it is right or wrong or any reference to review a specific lecture.

Are there flaws? Yes, plenty but the flaws are far outweighed by the benefits and enjoyment delivered and for the value of the course.

I'll be brief with the flaws. Leslie makes a couple of mistakes in code but doesn't realise it. Both of these mistakes I highlight in the Q&A. You know I said this is two courses, one new and one old? The course doesn't tell us that at all. There is no video explaining this. They just let you discover that yourself. I think that is naughty of the Eduonix company to do that. But you can see for yourself if you expand the course content, you will see that Section 6 is "Introduction to HTML"....which of course we already get that from section 1. 

If you want to develop and publish a good looking responsive website with user form interaction and feel accomplished in knowing the root language of your website so that you have complete control on every detail, and you want to learn this FAST and enjoy the journey with an energetic, playful instructor then I highly recommend this course.

UPDATE: 18 days later.  I originally gave this 5 stars and it is a 5 star course in terms of content delivered and the excellent delivery.  But I will now deduct half a star because it seems after I finished the course, the teaching assistants have been absent ever since.  If this coninues to be the case for another two weeks, I will reduce my rating further to reflect.  I care deeply not just for my own development but for my fellow students whos questions are not being answered.

results.content:
To begin with, I didnt enjoy the delivery, but, as time went on, I appreciated the way "Brad" took you through the elements of HTML5. It's certainly thorough and covers all the elements of HTML5 you will need.... And here would be my issue which is that the last section relies heavily on Javascript. 

In retrospect, I would suggest taking out the last project and instead adding a development module which allows you to go into these elements in more detail.

But well worth it overall

results.content: Having tried a number of online video tutorials,  including HTML, this one is poor by comparison. The trainer appears to need training in how to train; delivery is dry with a tendency toward tedium. I could only sit through about two videos at a time; it just seemed to drag.  I was frustrated that his screen was filmed at such a distance that it was difficult to see what he was typing. I  really wanted to like this course, I really did, but it just was not good quality, and lacked polish and engaging delivery. The content of the course appears fine, it just needs better delivery. Sorry.

I was frustrated that his screen was filmed at such a distance that it was difficult to see what he was typing. I really wanted to like this course, I really did, but it just was not good quality, and lacked polish and engaging delivery. The content of the course appears fine, it just needs better delivery. results.content:
Just too many "sorry but I can't explain this here" bits in this course imho. Here is a suggestion about that: If you really can't find the space in the course to explain what you are showing the students then LEAVE IT OUT. Design your course better with only teachable stuff in it. That's why we take the courses - to be taught, not to hear excuses about how you can't go into the material.

Additionally, very frustrating to have to sit though (and work through) "oh, that isn't working! wonder why?" bits. Especially when the students have to double back and make the corrections that the tutor is making. Believe me it is all hard enough for most of us without having to deal with tutor errors and have to listen to "emm'ing" and umm'ing" while the poorly planned lecture is sorted out in student time. Sort it all out BEFORE you publish the instruction videos - not during.

And the big incomprehensible javascript sections near the end - that get little to no explanation whatsoever had me hit the fast forward button after genuinely wrestling with it all for the first half of it. When the example code hit the long concatenated lines of javascript and JSON parsing I waved the white flag.

Have said all that I did learn quite a bit from this course. Just a bit of a wasted opportunity imho due to the spontaneous and seeming largely unplanned approach to the lectures that the tutor takes.

results.content:
One big concern - although the course was helpful in getting the basics of writing the code - there doesn't seem to be any information on how to take that code and get it up on the internet. Without that context, I'm pretty lost about what to do next.

Another big concern - the "Blue Developer Group" website he shows us how to build over the course of Sections 1-3 is awesome. But for sections 4-5, where all the advanced HTML5 features are -  he doesn't use any real world examples. As a result, I'm really not sure how/when to use those features at all.

results.content:
The course is easy to follow since the developer is commenting the screen recording while he is doing the coding of an example website. There are many useful hints during the course that junior programmers might want to know and the instructor is clearly describing his work. He is not perfectionist and makes common errors during teaching thus creating to the viewer the feeling as if he are in real classroom and practising in real time. No video editing in that manner which I think is ok in this case. There are resource files for this course so that students may work as they watch, though it's better option to first watch and listen and try it yourself afterwards.
Great course for beginners in any way. No time wasted here :)

results.content: Great first part, geting into basics of HTML5, CSS and a little of JS. The second part is from Y2013, which is pretty much outdated, e.g. not every browser support for HTML5, which is standart these days. As well as some bootstrap examples was not where the course tell they should be, because the page has several changes and you have to get basic code by yourself.  Daily planner project is a lot in JS and JQ and if you haven't any knowledge in those, you will not understand and learn to create any functions, because lectures just copy-paste several things and states - there's this and there should be that, without explaining why. Next step definately is learning JS to be able to understand and create such a project independetly. Overall, learned a lot about basics of HTML, CSS. Keep on goin'

results.content:
Not only is this one of the best HTML courses I've taken so far; it's completely free.  Instead of being super flashy, having a pointless 20 second intro video with lame dubstep playing and some graphic playing that was made in 10 minutes in After Effects, he gets straight to the point- teaching HTML.  One of the best aspects of this course so far is that the instructor, while extremely skilled, seems to know (and point out) his limitations/struggles.  If he gets stuck on something, instead of just cutting it out of the final product that we're watching, he instead keeps it in, which lets the students actually see and hear what his mental processes are for finding and correcting errors.  There was also a part in the javascript section where he didn't completely understand an equation you have to use to make a circle appear correctly (Math.PI * 2), and instead of attempting to fumble through an explanation that he himself didn't understand, he simply admitted that he didn't understand it, which I completely respect.
  The ONLY con is that sometimes the video zooms in on whatever is being talked about, but it doesn't get zoomed back out until much later, which, at certain points, makes it so you are unable to see what he's currently typing/clicking.  A minor complaint and just an obvious oversight, but the fact that everything else about this course is so informative and helpful and FREE keeps me from taking a star away for this.
results.content_html:
Not only is this one of the best HTML courses I've taken so far; it's completely free. Instead of being super flashy, having a pointless 20 second intro video with lame dubstep playing and some graphic playing that was made in 10 minutes in After Effects, he gets straight to the point- teaching HTML. One of the best aspects of this course so far is that the instructor, while extremely skilled, seems to know (and point out) his limitations/struggles. If he gets stuck on something, instead of just cutting it out of the final product that we're watching, he instead keeps it in, which lets the students actually see and hear what his mental processes are for finding and correcting errors. There was also a part in the javascript section where he didn't completely understand an equation you have to use to make a circle appear correctly (Math.PI * 2), and instead of attempting to fumble through an explanation that he himself didn't understand, he simply admitted that he didn't understand it, which I completely respect.
The ONLY con is that sometimes the video zooms in on whatever is being talked about, but it doesn't get zoomed back out until much later, which, at certain points, makes it so you are unable to see what he's currently typing/clicking. A minor complaint and just an obvious oversight, but the fact that everything else about this course is so informative and helpful and FREE keeps me from taking a star away for this.

results.content:
this course gives a good overview of html5 and its new tags and features.  To grasp the concepts fully, students should have prior knowledge of Javascript.  

At times, the instructor screen is too small to allow students to see exactly what he is typing, sometimes he copies text from another source to save time, but it only causes grief for the student who can't see what the code says.  The instructor should use the "pan in" feature of the video software to zoom to those areas.

A good course, and the I'm sure the instructor worked very hard on it.  Thanks for providing it free. -- a good start!

results.content: Overall the explanations are good. The videos don't feel hugely professional, in places where things go wrong there doesn't seem to be any direction to fixing issues. Although part of programming is the problem solving, in a training series where you're teaching someone completely new this becomes confusing more than it does helpful. results.content:
Although it is a free course it doesn't justify it being so poorly designed. The instructor gets very confused during the tutorials which make them hard to follow. The workflow has not been considered and he is constantly correcting himself. The code itself is impossible to read on the video due to the size of it. The construction of tutorial overall is a mess.

It is very clear to see that this is their first attempt and that is why it has been released for free so that they can use these reviews to better their courses and ultimately start selling them.

However simple research would have shown them all the points I have raised. This is by far the worst tutorial series I have ever watched...

I took this course and It was good, but I don't feel that I am an expert or I am ready to develop a project. This was more like an amateur teaching to beginners, and it was ok, but not much when the teacher has some errors in his presentation or even in the coding process. 

Also, I don't think W3Schools is true source of documentation for an HTML5 course, W3Schools are not part of W3C (the world wide web consortium). If you want a documentation for HTML standards go to the Wiki of W3C (http://www.w3.org/wiki/Main_Page).

In conlusion, this is a good course if you have the basics. But there are better courses out there.

results.content: Just completed the Tables and List section. The files were not in text when opened. They were HTML. Had to view source on each one in order to reveal code to copy and paste. About a third of the way through the tutorial, following the exact steps to move the lists to the right, the numbers and bullet points were transposed under the tables. Went through the tutorial three times with the same results. The tutorial showed it as happening seamlessly. I had to go to the finished document code, and copy and paste the styling for the lists <div> in order to move them w/o the transposing. I was too burned out to try step-by-step to find out which attribute in the styling changed it. Felt really good though when I figured out how to fix it w/o the aid of the tutorial.

There are numerous instances where prior knowledge is assumed or very difficult areas such as FlexBox and CSS Grid are explained in a haphazard manner. I.e., It is not presented in a systematic manner to convey the subject matter adequately. Note taking is a nightmare because of the presentation style.

This is a nightmare of chaos. Halfway through the course it reverts back to basic HTML and CSS by another person whose presentation is only slightly better than the first person. The files that he is referring to are not the ones in the resources etc.

This is shocking.

results.content: Instructor skipped over alot of content and I recognized that my main.js file did not match completely as I was going along step by step through the tutorials. I felt as though it was a waste of time as I couldn't figure out what I was doing wrong and feel that the instructor should have called out certain pain points. I used the console log to track the errors but that still didn't make sense as to why my code would not register correctly. Also, the discussion forum is a joke as I could not get any response for an entire day and honestly don't know what's the turn-time for a response for assistance. This course needs more polishing up.

I got frustrated with this course. I followed along but the video is really blurry on the Surface Pro 3 I am using so there were times where I could not see the code he was typing.

I am going to try another course.

results.content:
This is really a good course/training for beginners. Now that I have completed the course, I can definitely say I learned some basic knowledge about HTML5 & its features and can apply it to real world applications. 

Look like this course was built sometime during 2013-2014, and I found it little difficult to understand project specific details while using bootstrap framework code, but it was still manageable. As part of my practice I also used Microsoft Visual Code IDE which kind of great for HTML5 programming.

This course is really good and engaging. Thanks very much to instructor. I would definitely recommend this course to other learners.
I am looking forward to take my knowledge to next step with more practice and learning new HTML5 stuff.
results.content_html:
This is really a good course/training for beginners. Now that I have completed the course, I can definitely say I learned some basic knowledge about HTML5 & its features and can apply it to real world applications.

Look like this course was built sometime during 2013-2014, and I found it little difficult to understand project specific details while using bootstrap framework code, but it was still manageable. As part of my practice I also used Microsoft Visual Code IDE which kind of great for HTML5 programming.

This course is really good and engaging. Thanks very much to instructor. I would definitely recommend this course to other learners.
I am looking forward to take my knowledge to next step with more practice and learning new HTML5 stuff.

results.content: This was a good entry into HTML5. The instructor creates nice and easy to follow projects and is generally easy to listen to. He was pretty funny at times and I enjoyed his humor and manner of speech. There were a couple of times my brother and I had some good laughs. The javascript was a little sketchy to learn and still do not understand the full scope, but as this being an HTML5 course it is not required. The only thing I would say is negative is that the structure of files, and some of the code, included in the downloadable material slightly differed from what the video portrayed. Easy to follow along if you could grasp the concepts but a few times proved confusing. All in all I would say excellent course and thank you for the info sir.

results.content:
As of right now I have finished the first few sections of this course. Very thorough presentation of HTML and CSS's inner-workings, through extensive examples/ cohesive sample project. I will be interested to see how 'advanced' the presenter gets by the end of the course.

(For reference, I have a fairly extensive background in object-oriented programming, but no prior experience in front-end web design. I expect that a student with no programming history would still be able to approach this course with minimal difficulty.)

EDIT: Still really great content, but in some of the presenter's videos, he gets "stumped" and has to look around in his code for the error. (It never takes long; finds it after, at most, ~20 seconds of looking around; but still, this could have been avoided or at least cut-out of the finished product).  If you are a completely novice student, it can actually be kind of nice to have the break from trying to absorb the material, as well as being a part of the troubleshooting process that you will inevitably run into as you take on your own projects. However, for a more experienced programmer (even if new to HTML5), this can be slightly irksome. Still, not a deal breaker. Good content overall. Now halfway through the course, I have learned the building blocks of HTML/HTML5/CSS3 and *some* JavaScript, and feel that I now have the building blocks to begin crafting a clean front-end.
results.content_html:

results.content:
The whole course is built on the instructor simply making things along the way with no planning at all. As a consequence, it is not a "HTML course" per se, it's more of a showcase of several code snippets to give the student SOME basis on what makes HTML.

To me this was actually more beneficial since I wasn't really looking forward to a massively comprehensive guide to HTML, just wanted to know the basics to not be a complete illiterate.

But assessing the course based on its QUALITY? It is really subpar.

results.content: In the first three or so sections, the instructor does a great job at lecturing about the basics of HTML as well as HTML5 and CSS. However, the moment he started going into Javascript, you WILL be lost IF you do not have any knowledge with Javascript. His approach towards Javascript is as if he assumes everyone knows Javascript. Not only that, but he goes straight into it with no prior fundamentals to Javascript. I thought this course was going to teach ONLY HTML5 and CSS3, but Javascript? I'm all for it if he was able to give the fundamentals and basics of Javascript, but he just went for it. Also the material isn't so engaging. The "projects" aren't engaging for the audience. We just follow along with what he does and we barely have any freedom to test out what we learned.

results.content:
"Is the content comprehensive and informative?" - I can't honestly answer that for the entire course, since I bailed out very early. I (and many others, based on the comments) ran into a number of issues with the first real lesson. For starters, the downloaded materials didn't match what was described in the presentation. Then the screenshot in the video was zoomed in on the browser window, so the relevant window where the code was being entered was not even being shown. When this was brought up in the comments, the response was the equivalent of "deal with it" for all intents and purposes. That specific phrase was not used, but we were told to open up the code for the finished page and follow with that, which seems to defeat the format of the lesson which was entering the code piece by piece. I think the cavalier, unapologetic attitude of the instructor bothered me more than anything else, to be honest.

"Does the production quality meet your expectations?" - I guess it was worth what I paid for it: nothing.

"Is the instructor's delivery interesting and engaging?" - Not at all. Even he seemed bored with his own material.

results.content:
I really liked this course. It taught me a lot about HTML5, and CSS, which I can use in my own projects later on. Also the projects you do get from this course are a good base to start from. 

However there are some points when the instructor is typing some JQuery and what's going on is not clearly explained. I understand the course is primarily about HTML5 and CSS, but it would have been better if the javaScript, and JQuery code was thoroughly explained. 

My recommendation for anyone taking this course is to type out the code alongside the instructor. Don't just copy and paste. You will learn a lot more by typing, in my opinion.
results.content_html:

My recommendation for anyone taking this course is to type out the code alongside the instructor. Don't just copy and paste. You will learn a lot more by typing, in my opinion.

results.content: This course is a good starting point for learning HTML and helped me to understand the basics.  The course was pretty easy to follow and presented in a simple way.  I would have liked it better if the instructor went into a little more detail when explaining things, such as why he's doing certain things.  A few times he said do "one thing" rather than do "another thing" and it would have been helpful for me to understand why.  Overall, I thought this was a good introduction and his Boston accent made me a little homesick.

results.content:
The organization seems to be lacking by the "teacher", not only in setting up the sections but also in the videos. Some of the discussion in the code-it-yourself videos is all over the place, which I don't feel should happen since it is a pre-recorded video & not a livestream. 

Also, in the end of the first section he cited information from w3schools which is not a reliable source for web coding/design. If this had not been a free course, I would have demanded my money back after that because that loses credibility in my book.

There was also a few other little mistakes that surprised me, like the multiple occurrences of an id early in section 2. 

Yes, you can learn some of the basics from this course. But I find that having a strong & solid foundation is the best place to start an education, which this course might not be.
results.content_html:

There was also a few other little mistakes that surprised me, like the multiple occurrences of an id early in section 2.

Yes, you can learn some of the basics from this course. But I find that having a strong & solid foundation is the best place to start an education, which this course might not be.

El contenido me parece estar correcto, los ejercicios también. Sin embargo, hay cierta desorganización en el instructor que hace parecer que el curso no lleva un sentido en ciertos momentos. Tiene errores que pudo haber evitado, mejores formas para explicar las cosas, paquetes zips incompletos, repeticiones y errores en la edición de sus clases, etc. Para ser un curso el cual estás pagando, esperarías que fuera de mucha más calidad.

Content is ok but the instructor lacks organization: there are multiple errores in his videos, repetitions, editing mistakes, bad zip files, and all this gives a poor sense if direction that you would expect from a course for absolute beginners. You'll get disappointed if you pay the full cash for this course cause it really has to be improved.

results.content: The coarse was very informative and easy to follow at the beginning. The instructor went into detail thoroughly explaining the tags and the syntax. Once the instructor started getting into jquerry and java, I started to get lost. He used a lot of code that he stated he was not going to explain how it works or the syntax. This does note correlate with the title of the course being called "Learning HTML5 Programming from Scratch. Another shortcoming of the course was that there was no way for me to apply the knowledge to projects to gauge understanding, all I did was follow the tutorials and type up what he did. It would have been a more valuable course if he set up projects to do on my own and supplied the solution code.  I gave the coarse an overall score of 3 stars because the beginning was very helpful.
